textos_fuente.text: Updated Non-Emergency Telephone Number MEDIA CONTACT Misti Guertin, Communications and Digital Marketing Manager Office: (772) 600-1250, Cell: (772) 285-6850, Email: mguertin@ci.stuart.fl.us UPDATED NON-EMERGENCY TELEPHONE INFO City of Stuart Incoming Telephone Lines Experiencing Widespread Service Issue STUART, FL (September 15, 2022) – Inbound telephone lines to the City of Stuart are experiencing a widespread service issue due to a phone carrier issue. 911 SERVICES ARE OPERATIONAL. Non-emergency Stuart Police Department telephone calls may be made to (772) 600-0119. Technicians are investigating the issue and hope to have all inbound telephone lines operational as quickly as possible. An update and estimated timeline for the return of services will be given once technicians finish their assessment. # # # Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share via Email Copyright ? 2022 City of Stuart. News Flash Press Releases & Public Notices Posted on: May 8, 2023 [ARCHIVED] Flagler Park Playground Temporarily Closed MEDIA CONTACT:  Misti Guertin, Communications and Digital Media Manager EMAIL: mguertin@ci.stuart.fl.us or (772) 600-1250 Flagler Park Playground temporarily closed may 9-17, 2023 (STUART, Fla) May 8, 2023 -- It's maintenance and repair time for the Flagler Park Playground. The playground will be closed from May 9 to May 17, 2023. Please visit one of the other City of Stuart playgrounds in the interim. Thank you for your understanding. Administration / City Manager | Flagler Beach, FL - Official Website Skip to Main Content Create a Website Account - Manage notification subscriptions, save form progress and more. Website Sign In Search Government Services Community How Do I… Come Visit Home Government Departments Executive / City Manager Administration / City Manager We are pleased to present the City's First Annual Report . Mr. Martin is a native of metropolitan Detroit, Michigan, and father of three daughters, Emily (Curtis), Abigail, and Meaghan (Klaassen), and grandfather to Boston Curtis. He received his graduate degree in Public Administration (Oakland University) in 1990, and then served as an infantry and intelligence officer in the United States Army, stationed in Schweinfurt, Bavaria, Germany until 1994. He began his municipal career in Lexington, Michigan, in 1996, and successively served the communities of Linden, Michigan; Dowagiac, Michigan; Davison, Michigan; Winsted, Connecticut; and Fernandina Beach, Florida, before beginning his service to Flagler Beach in Aug, 2023. He was previously credentialed by the International City/County Managers Association and retains his Professional Emergency Manager certification from the Michigan State Police. Mr. Martin served for several years as a member of the Presbyterian Disaster Assistance National Response Team, providing long-term recovery support for communities affected by floods, tornadoes, and other natural disasters. His personal interests include playing boardgames and reading. March 21, 2025/Friday Notes As the community has been promoting all year, Flagler Beach is celebrating its centennial anniversary this year. The Town of Flagler Beach was originally incorporated in 1925 (subsequently becoming a City in 1963). Mayor Patti King is leading a committee to develop and host a series of celebratory events throughout the year, beginning with a birthday party on April 16, the same date as the Town’s incorporation. The City is offering sponsorship opportunities for the Centennial Celebrations. The sponsorship levels are Gold ($5,000), Silver ($2,500), and Bronze ($1,000). Sponsors at each level will be recognized for their support throughout the year through a variety of means: City Commission recognition, social media, City website, print, and other promotional materials. Planned events include an ice cream social, a community dinner, a return of the downtown “bed races,” a cardboard regatta, a historic scavenger hunt, and a gala dinner. The year will also be celebrated with banners on the Moody Boulevard (SR 100) bridge and other local streets; regular First Friday events and other holiday festivities; and culminate with the City’s New Year’s Eve Surfboard Drop and Fireworks. The Calendar of Events can be found on the City’s website and Facebook page. Please send your Sponsorship donation to City of Flagler Beach, ATTN: Ms. Hollie Harlan, Finance Director, 105 S. 2nd Street, Flagler Beach, FL, 32136, hharlan@cityofflaglerbeach.com. Please also provide an electronic copy of your logo so that your sponsorship can be officially recognized, along with a preferred web link to your website that can be promoted on sponsorship material. Thank you for your support. The City looks forward to working with you as the next one hundred years begin! If you have any questions, please contact me or Ms. Katherine Monroy, Executive Assistant (kmonroy@cityofflaglerbeach.com). Before you head to a park, please check its page or head to our alerts page for closures, alerts and other important information to make sure you have a fun, safe and informed trip. Reservations Discover Pass About Us Find Parks Find Sno-Parks Find Activities Get Involved Passes & Permits Menu Search Search Home Find Parks Fort Flagler Historical State Park Alerts Burn Ban  Level 3 Posted on: June 25, 2025 Ends on: November 25, 2025 Gas/propane self-contained camping stoves and portable gas/propane fire pits allowed. No charcoal or wood fires allowed. Construction Posted on: May 22, 2025 There is construction at the entrance of the park. This work starts at the end of May and will last through August. The work includes construction of a new Welcome Center, bathrooms, park office, and improved roadways. Expect construction noise and occasional stopping of traffic at the park entrance. See all photos Fort Flagler Historical State Park 10541 Flagler Road, 
             Nordland, WA 98358 Fort Flagler Historical State Park is a camping park surrounded on three sides by saltwater shoreline and offers historic forts, military history and much more. Hours Summer: 6:30 a.m.

Cell service varies depending on your carrier and location within the park. All pets must be kept on leashes throughout the park, as there is no designated off-leash area. Cougars have been spotted occasionally, so keep your pets close and children nearby for safety. For more information on cougar sightings, refer to the Fact Sheet .             Dusk Fees Discover pass: Annual Pass: $30 One-day Pass: $10 Nightly Moorage: $23 for buoy, $1 per vessel foot for dock Watercraft Launch Fee: $7 for the day Trailer Dump Fee: $5 per use Entrance fees: Varies Overnight Unattended Vehicle Fee: $10 per night See more about fees Contact Email fort.flagler@parks.wa.gov Phone (360) 385-1259 Reservations Get Directions Get Discover Pass 20 Sep 2025 International Coastal Cleanup 9:00am - 12:00pm Map & visitor guide Locate 48.085842, -122.701643 File Fort-Flagler-Campground-Map.pdf File Fort-Flagler-Metal-Detecting.pdf File Fort-Flagler-Trail-Map_0.pdf File Fort Flagler Wildlife.pdf Things to do at this park Offering unparalleled views of the Olympic and Cascade mountains and Puget Sound, historic Fort Flagler features many of the original military buildings used during the turn of the 20th century including gun batteries, noncommissioned officers' quarters and the hospital. Camping The Lower Campground offers standard, partial, and full-hookup sites that are level and spacious, with views of the waterway or forest. The Upper Campground has standard sites in a forested, more private setting. Both campgrounds have easy access to trails and restrooms with showers. Reservations are necessary April-October as campsites are popular and fill quickly. Camper check-in can be done at the Welcome Station or through self-registration at the campground bulletin board. Please note that there is a prickly native ground covering plant in grassy areas around the Lower Campground and Shelter. For more information, please read the Sandmat Flyer in English or the Spanish version of the Sandmat Flyer . Winter Schedule Learn about seasonal closers and operational changes during the off-season on the Winter Schedule page . Trails and activities Fort Flagler features both beach and wooded trails. Other popular activities include visiting the museum, taking an interpretive tour of the historic hospital and gun batteries, embarking on a scavenger hunt around the park, paragliding, hiking, boating, kite-flying, beach exploration, saltwater fishing, clam digging and crabbing. There is also a small playground in the day-use area across from the Lower Campground, as well as a basketball half-court and swings at the end of Flagler Road next to the Battery Row trailhead. View a video tour of the park to see more of what Fort Flagler has to offer. Boating and moorage There is one single-lane boat launch ramp, which drops gently down the beach north of the floats. 256 feet of moorage is available seasonally at this park. Moorage fees are charged at docks, floats, and buoys from 1 p.m. to 8 a.m. Moorage is closed in the winter. Picnic and day use facilities Take in beautiful views of the waterway, Olympic and Cascade Mountains, or historic structures while enjoying your lunch at one of the many picnic and day use areas. You can also purchase meals, snacks, and supplies from the concession near the Lower Campground and main day use area. Reservable Shelter Located near the Lower Campground is a reservable picnic shelter that offers electrical outlets, water, a large BBQ brazier, and a firepit area. Groups hosting special events, such as weddings, must obtain a special activity permit. This requirement applies to all groups with more than 20 people, those using professional photography, or those bringing in outside vendors. Contact the park at (360) 302-7840 for information regarding a Special Activities Permit . Concessions Beachcomber Cafe Beachcomber Café serves up hot sandwiches and burgers as well as a variety of beverages including espresso. They also have snacks and grocery items, beach toys, clothing, camping supplies, bagged ice and firewood. The Beachcomber Café is open weekends in April, May, and September and daily Memorial Day through Labor Day. Hours are 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. but are subject to change. Visit them on Facebook . Olympic Kayak Tours Experience the magic of wildlife, sunsets, and bioluminescence on our guided tours led by our expert naturalists. Enjoy birdwatching, spot seals, and take in breathtaking views. For more details or to book your tour, visit our website or find us on Instagram . Service Projects Are you interested in giving back to the park? Great! Groups interested in volunteering with parks must complete a group volunteer application and contact the park two months prior to your visit. If you are also interested in a group program, please see the Interpretive Opportunities section below. Interpretive opportunities Fort Flagler Museum Explore Fort Flagler’s Museum , featuring displays about the fort and military life at the turn of the 20th century. This state park museum is free to visit, though donations are greatly appreciated. Families, be sure to ask the volunteer host about a scavenger hunt. The museum is located on the Upper Campus of the park. When entering the park, follow Flagler Rd straight through the 4-way stop, and the museum will be the first building with parking, on the right. Operating hours: 11 a.m. - 4 p.m. April - May: Wed.- Sun. June - July: Daily Aug.: Daily Sept. - Oct.: Wed. - Sun. Nov. - March: Saturdays Interested in learning more about the historical sites around the park? Join a volunteer-led walking tour offered April-August to learn more about historical fort operations and what life was like for the soldiers that once lived here. Tours have been cancelled for the month of August due to volunteer availability. Visit the museum for more information or keep an eye on the Upcoming Events Calendar for the dates and times of the Historical Hospital Tour, Historical Gun Emplacement Tours, and more . Group tours and activities Are you planning a visit to Fort Flagler State Park with your family, scout group, club, or co-workers? Add a fun, interactive, and educational experience to your trip by filling out the Group Program Request Form . View the program descriptions to learn more about the types of programs offered. Tours and programs Join ranger-led programs about nature and history. Stop by the office, welcome station, or museum to learn about the Junior Ranger program. Also be sure to keep an eye on the Upcoming Events Calendar . Networking Interviewing Negotiating Search Firms Career Videos & Handouts Lifelong Learning Giving New Building Contact us Alumni Council Our Alumni Engagement Alumni Council Since its founding in the fall of 2006, the Alumni Council has been a powerful connector, offering Dean’s Circle donors a meaningful way to stay closely engaged with the School’s programs, leadership, and mission. This exclusive group of alumni not only supports the School through their time, expertise, and resources, but also strengthens the bonds that unite our alumni community and ensures the continued success of future generations of Business Tar Heels. Be part of something bigger Joining the Alumni Council is about more than just giving back—it’s about creating lasting connections, sharing your insights, and contributing to the future of our community. As a member, you’ll play a role in shaping the direction of UNC Kenan-Flagler, working alongside our passionate alumni network, and empowering future leaders. Whether through networking, mentorship, or thought leadership, the Alumni Council amplifies the power of a UNC Kenan-Flagler degree by connecting alumni with students and each other. It’s an opportunity to be a part of a community that celebrates achievement, fosters growth, and creates pathways for success. Building stronger connections together The Alumni Council partners closely with the UNC Kenan-Flagler Advancement team to support and grow the School’s alumni community. As volunteers, advisors and ambassadors, Alumni Council members help expand the impact of our shared UNC Kenan-Flagler experience. Through their dedication, we build a network that not only strengthens alumni connections but also enriches the lives of students by providing mentorship and career opportunities. By working together, we can continue to elevate the UNC Kenan-Flagler experience for alumni and students alike — fostering a sense of community that lasts a lifetime. Create your legacy We invite you to take an active role in the future of UNC Kenan-Flagler by becoming a member of the Alumni Council. By getting involved, you’ll not only contribute to the ongoing success of the School, but also leave a lasting legacy for future generations of Business Tar Heels. Together, we are building a community that thrives on connection, growth, and the shared pride of being a part of UNC Kenan-Flagler. Join Us For more information, reach out to Jessa Nelson at Jessa_Nelson@kenan-flagler.unc.edu . Membership Expectations As a member of the UNC Kenan-Flagler Alumni Council, you’ll have the opportunity to actively support and strengthen our School. Members are expected to: Attend in-person meetings: Participate in two on-campus meetings and special events each year, held in the spring and fall in Chapel Hill. Make a meaningful contribution: Support the School’s continued excellence with an annual gift of $2,000 to any fund at UNC Kenan-Flagler. Engage with fellow alumni: Contribute to Alumni Council initiatives, which could include joining a working committee, and participate in exclusive events like the Dean’s Circle Reception. Meetings We bring our key alumni volunteers from across the globe back to UNC Kenan-Flagler twice a year to receive School and Advancement updates, hear from featured programs or faculty across the School and University, and participate in networking and professional development opportunities. In the spring, we offer a half day meeting and host on Alumni Weekend. The fall meeting is combined with a football weekend and includes a full day meeting on Friday with a Dean’s Circle reception that evening and the alumni tailgate that Saturday. Members cover the cost of their travel to the meetings and their own room accommodations. Travel and related expenses may be tax deductible for such volunteer activities. UNC Kenan-Flagler provides food and beverages the night before or after the meeting, as well as breakfast and lunch on the day of the meeting. Committees Giving committee partners with the Advancement team to encourage more alumni to contribute to the School each year. Campus Engagement committee encourages alumni to connect with the School through signature on-campus and regional events. Digital Engagement committee enhances the School’s opportunities for alumni to stay connected and engaged from any location. Alumni Connections committee helps alumni feel connected to the School where they live and work and encourages alumni and students to interact in meaningful ways. Membership committee (by invitation only) educates fellow alumni on opportunities to engage deeper with the School through opportunities like the Alumni Council, and identifies ways to optimize the council experience for members. Membership Application and Terms of Service The Alumni Council is looking for alumni who are enthusiastic and dedicated to attending meetings, actively participating in discussions, and offering their time and support to the School. These are important factors for a meaningful and successful membership experience. The membership term lasts for three years, with the possibility of a two-year extension, subject to approval by the dean, Advancement Office and chair of the council. Interested alumni can contact Jessa Nelson at Jessa_Nelson@kenan-flagler.unc.edu for a brief conversation and to receive application form. The Membership Committee reviews applications every March and April. Those selected will receive an invitation to join the next Alumni Council cohort in June, with the first meeting scheduled for fall. She is a Phi Beta Kappa graduate from the University of North Carolina where sbe was inducted into Beta Gamma Sigma, a business honorary fraternity. She earned her MBA degree from the University of Kansas. With an emphasis on continuing education, she earned the Certified Financial Planner (CFP®) certification and the designation of Certified Investment Management Analyst (CIMA®) after successfully completing the courses offered through the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania in 1998. She was a founding member of the Women’s Capital Connection, a regional network of accredited angel investors dedicated to identifying and funding promising women led start-up businesses in the region. She received the Joan Strewler-Carter Women of Influence Award in 2008 for her role in significantly impacting women entrepreneurship in the community. She is active in the community, serving on many boards and committees including the University of Kansas Business School Advisory Board, Cristo Rey High School Board, Diocesan Finance Council and William Jewell College board of trustees. Director : Stephanie Burgess ASL Lab and Tutoring American Sign Language (ASL) tutors are available to students who are taking any ASL courses at Flagler College. Please refer to the points below for more information: Tutoring hours can be found at this link: ASL Tutoring Hours To schedule a tutoring appointment, students must email Asllab@flagler.edu . Within this email, students should include their name, ASL Level, Professor's name, and preferred meeting time so that they may be assigned a tutor.  Students can also request tutoring via this link: Schedule a Tutoring Appointment Once your request has been reviewed by one of our lab assistants, you will receive an Outlook calendar invitation with the appointment time and the tutor you will be working with. Please note that you will not receive this email instantly, but if you haven’t received a follow-up email within 24 hours, please contact us again. Tutoring appointments can be conducted via Zoom, whereby.com [no login required] or in person. Therefore, we recommend that all students download For Whereby.com appointments, please use this: Whereby.com/FlaglerASL We request that both students and tutors join the meeting ~5 minutes prior to the tutoring appointment. Our Purpose Flagler constructed the Crisp-Ellert Art Museum in honor of Dr. JoAnn Crisp-Ellert and her husband, Dr. Robert Ellert. More than just a gallery space, CEAM offers Flagler College students and the Northeast Florida community a venue for fostering knowledge and a deep appreciation of contemporary art. As an educational resource for the College, the Museum exhibits regional, national, and international artists and provides opportunities for critical engagement and exposure to a variety of exhibitions and personal interactions with visiting artists. The Museum challenges students, the Flagler community, and the public to cultivate individual creativity, critical reflection, historical consciousness, and respect for the free exchange of ideas. In this spirit, the Museum also hosts public programs, including artist talks, readings, panel discussions, and film series that provide a platform for vital interdisciplinary dialogue. Learn more about our unique history and the forward thinkers who made the Crisp-Ellert Art Museum possible.
